data.name: Prompt_CommandNotFound.Text

data.name: Prompt_CommandHelpLearn.Text
data.value:
Understanding Prompt Commands

As with most command line interfaces, the more commands you memorize, the more efficient you can be. Understanding the reasoning behind how Prompt commands are named and structured will make it much easier to learn and internalize them.

  1. Prompt is Case-Insensitive. That means you can use lowercase, uppercase or mixed-case command names and option flag names. This is typical of most command lines and we find it makes it easier to use on a daily basis.
  2. Commands are either 1 word or 2 words separated by a single dash (-) and no spaces.
  3. One-Word Commands: These are generally reserved for commands that interact with the Prompt console itself or the browser. In other words, most of these commands take place in the browser. Some examples are: cls which clears the console screen and reload which tells the browser to reload the page. There are also two-word commands that operate on the client side such as clear-history (though there is a shortcut for clear-history: clh
  4. Two-Word Commands: These commands follow the format action-component—an action followed by a single dash followed by a component or object that the action operates on.

Common Actions

This is not a complete list of all actions but covers most of them...

Action Description
list Retrieves a list of objects. The assumption is that two or more objects will be returned so the component portion of the command is plural:
list-pages NOT list-page
get Will retrieve a single object. If the command results in multiple objects, only the fist object found will be retrieved. Since this command operates on a single item, the component is singular and not plural:
get-page NOT get-pages
new Creates a new object. We chose the word new since it requires less typing than 'create' and it is a more accurate than 'add', which connotes adding something to something else.
add Adds something to something else. This should not be confused with new which creates a new object. Consider add-roles and new-role. The former is used to add one or more security roles to a user (i.e. add a role to the list of roles the user already has), whereas the latter command creates a new security role in the DNN system.
set Modifies an object. This could mean 'update' or set (for the first time) a value. We chose the word 'set' not only because it's short and easy to type, but also because it is more accurate in more scenarios. 'Update' implies you are changing a value that has already been set, but is less accurate if you are setting a value for the first time. And did we mention 'set' is half the length of 'update'?
delete Deletes an object. The results of this action are contextually dependent. If DNN provides a recycle bin facility like it does for pages and users, then the command will send the object to that recycle bin, allowing it to be restored later. If there is no such facility provided, then the object would be permanently deleted.
restore If an object has been previously deleted and DNN provides a recycle facility for the object, then this will restore the object.
purge If the object has been previously deleted and DNN provides a recycle facility for the object, then this command will permanently delete the object. The DNN user interface typically refers to this as 'remove' however we felt that 'purge' more accurately reflected the action.

Common Components

Most components should be familiar to any user with admin experience with DNN. Below are the most common:

A Note on Plural vs Singular Components: Whenever a command can 1 or more items, the component will be plural. list-modules, for instance. When the command is designed to return a single object or the first object, then the component will be singular as in get-module

Component Description
user/users A DNN User.
page/pages A page in the site. NOTE: For historical reasons, DNN refers to pages internally as Tabs while the DNN user interface refers to them as pages. We've chosen to use 'page', but you may see references to Tab or TabID returned from page-related commands. For Prompt's purposes, you should only use 'page' but understand that 'page and 'tab' are synonymous.
role/roles A DNN Security Role.
task/tasks A task is a DNN Scheduler Item or Scheduled Task. We use the word task due to its brevity.
portal/portals A DNN site or portal.
module/modules A DNN module. Depending on the command, this could be a module definition or module instance.

See Also

Basic Syntax Prompt Commands List

data.name: Prompt_CommandHelpSyntax.Text
data.value:
Basic Syntax

Prompt functions in a way similar to a Terminal, Bash shell, Windows CMD shell, or Powershell. You enter a command and hit ENTER and the computer responds with a result. For very simple commands like help or list-modules, that's all you need. Some commands, though, may require additional data or they may allow you to provide additional options.

Specifying a target or context for a command: For commands that operate on an object like a user, or that require a context like a page, you simply provide that information after the command. For example, to find the user jsmith using the get-user command, you would type: get-user jsmith followed by the ENTER key to submit it. If you will be specifying flags (see next paragraph), those should always come after the target/context of the command.

Specifying Options to Commands: Some commands require even more data or allow you to specify optional configuration information. In Prompt we call these "flags". These should come after any target/context needed by the command (see above paragraph) and must be preceded with two hyphens or dashes (--). There should be no spaces between the dashes and there should be no space between the dashes and the name of the flag. If then flag requires a value, you add that after the flag.

As an example of using flags, take the get-user command. By default, you would specify the username of the user you want to find. However, you can also search by their email address. In that case, you would use the --email flag. Here's how you would use it:

get-user --email jsmith@sample.com

If the value of a flag is more than one word, enclose it in double quotes like so:

set-page --title "My Page"

See Also

Learning Prompt Commands Prompt Commands List

data.name: Prompt_AddModule_Description.Text
data.value: Adds a module to a page on the website.

data.name: Prompt_AddModule_FlagModuleName.Text
data.value: Name of the desktop module to add. This should be unique existing module name.

data.name: Prompt_AddModule_FlagModuleTitle.Text
data.value: Specify the title of the module on the page.

data.name: Prompt_AddModule_FlagPageId.Text
data.value: Id of the page to add module on.

data.name: Prompt_AddModule_FlagPane.Text
data.value: Specify the pane in which the module should be added. If not provided, module would be added to ContentPane.

data.name: Prompt_AddModule_ResultHtml.Text
data.value:
Add a module to a page

add-module --name "Html" --pageid 23 --pane TopPane

data.name: Prompt_CopyModule_Description.Text
data.value: Copies a module to the specified page.

data.name: Prompt_CopyModule_FlagId.Text
data.value: Explicitly specifies the Module ID of the module to copy. Use of the flag is not required. You can simply provide the ID value as the first argument.

data.name: Prompt_CopyModule_FlagIncludesettings.Text
data.value: If true, Prompt will copy the source module's settings to the copied module.

data.name: Prompt_CopyModule_FlagPageId.Text
data.value: The Page ID of the page that contains the module you want to copy.

data.name: Prompt_CopyModule_FlagPane.Text
data.value: Specify the pane in which the module should be copied. If not provided, module would be copied to ContentPane.

data.name: Prompt_CopyModule_FlagToPageId.Text
data.value: The Page ID of the target page. The page to which you want to copy the module.

data.name: Prompt_DeleteModule_Description.Text
data.value: Soft-deletes a module on a specific page. The module will be sent to the DNN Recycle Bin. This will not uninstall modules or affect module definitions.

data.name: Prompt_DeleteModule_FlagId.Text
data.value: Explicitly specifies the Module ID of the module to retrieve. Use of the flag is not required. You can simply provide the ID value as the first argument.

data.name: Prompt_DeleteModule_FlagPageId.Text
data.value: Specifies the Page ID of the page on which the module to delete resides.

data.name: Prompt_DeleteModule_ResultHtml.Text
data.value:
Delete and Send Module Instance to Recycle Bin

This will delete a module instance on a specific page and send it to the DNN Recycle Bin

delete-module 345 --pageid 42

data.name: Prompt_GetModule_Description.Text
data.value: Retrieves details about a single module in a specified page

data.name: Prompt_GetModule_FlagId.Text
data.value: Explicitly specifies the Module ID of the module to retrieve. Use of the flag is not required. You can simply provide the ID value as the first argument.

data.name: Prompt_GetModule_FlagPageId.Text
data.value: The Page ID of the page that contains the module.

data.name: Prompt_GetModule_Result.Text
data.value: Module '{0}' has been found in page '{1}'.

data.name: Prompt_GetModule_ResultHtml.Text
data.value:
Get Information on a Specific Module

The code below retrieves the details for a module whose Module ID is 345 on a page 48

get-module 359 --pageid 48

The following version is a more explicit version of the code above, but does the same thing on a page 48.

get-module --id 359 --pageid 48

Results

ModuleId : 359
Title : Navigation
ModuleName : Console
FriendlyName : Console
ModuleDefId : 102
TabModuleId : 48
AddedToPages : 42, 46, 47, 48

data.name: Prompt_ListModules_Description.Text
data.value: Retrieves a list of modules based on the search criteria

data.name: Prompt_ListModules_FlagDeleted.Text
data.value: When specified, the command will find all module instances in the portal that are in the Recycle Bin (if --deleted is true), or all module instances not in the Recycle Bin (if --deleted is false). If the flag is specified but no value is given, it will default to true. This flag may be used with --name and --title to further refine the results.

data.name: Prompt_ListModules_FlagMax.Text
data.value: Page Size for the page. Max is 500.

data.name: Prompt_ListModules_FlagModuleName.Text
data.value: The name of the module to search for. This accepts the wildcard (*) character to do partial searches. The Module Name is not the same thing as the module's Friendly Name or the module's Title. To find the Module Name, list-modules on a page containing the module. Searches are case-insensitive

data.name: Prompt_ListModules_FlagModuleTitle.Text
data.value: The title of the module to search for. This accepts wildcard (*) placeholders representing 0 or more characters. Searches are case-insensitive.

data.name: Prompt_ListModules_FlagPage.Text
data.value: Page number to show records.

data.name: Prompt_ListModules_FlagPageId.Text
data.value: When specified, the command will show modules from specified page only. Use of the flag is not required. You can simply provide the ID value as the first argument.

data.name: Prompt_ListModules_ResultHtml.Text
data.value:
List Modules in the Current Portal

list-modules

List Modules on Specific Page

list-modules 72

List Modules Filtered by Module Name

This will return all XMod and XMod Pro modules in the current portal

list-modules --name XMod*

List Modules on a Specific Page Filtered by Module Name

This will return all XMod and XMod Pro modules on the page with a Page/TabId of 72

list-modules 72 --name XMod*

List All Modules Filtered on Name and Title

This will return all modules in the portal whose Module Name starts with Site and Title starts with Configure.

list-modules --title Configure* --name Site*

Returns

ModuleId Title ModuleName FriendlyName ModuleDefId TabModuleId AddedToPages
394 Configure portal settings, page design and apply a template... SiteWizard Site Wizard 88 86 64
395 Configure the sitemap for submission to common search engines Sitemap Sitemap 106 87 65

List All Deleted Modules in Portal

This will return all modules in the DNN Recycle Bin.

list-modules --deleted

Returns

ModuleId Title Pane ModuleName FriendlyName ModuleDefId TabModuleId IsDeleted TabId
358 Home Banner ContentPane DNN_HTML HTML 120 106 true 74
410 Module that was copied ContentPane DNN_HTML HTML 120 104 true 71

List All Deleted Modules Filtered on Name and Title

This will return all modules in the DNN Recycle Bin whose Module Name ends with "HTML" and whose Module Title contains "that".

list-modules --deleted --name *HTML --title *that*

Returns

ModuleId Title Pane ModuleName FriendlyName ModuleDefId TabModuleId IsDeleted TabId
410 Module that was copied ContentPane DNN_HTML HTML 120 104 true 71

data.name: Prompt_MoveModule_Description.Text
data.value: Moves a module to the specified page

data.name: Prompt_MoveModule_FlagId.Text
data.value: Explicitly specifies the Module ID of the module to copy. Use of the flag is not required. You can simply provide the ID value as the first argument.

data.name: Prompt_MoveModule_FlagPageId.Text
data.value: The Page ID of the page that contains the module you want to copy.

data.name: Prompt_MoveModule_FlagPane.Text
data.value: Specify the pane in which the module should be moved. If not provided, module would be moved to ContentPane.

data.name: Prompt_MoveModule_FlagToPageId.Text
data.value: The Page ID of the target page. The page to which you want to copy the module.

data.name: Prompt_MoveModule_ResultHtml.Text
data.value:
Move a Module from One Page to Another

This command takes the module with Module ID 358 on the Page with Page ID of 71 and places module on the page with a Page ID of 75

move-module 358 --pageid 71 --topageid 75

Results

ModuleId : 358
Title : My Module
ModuleName : DNN_HTML
FriendlyName : HTML
ModuleDefId : 120
TabModuleId : 107
AddedToPages : 71, 75
Successfully moved the module.

data.name: Prompt_ClearCache_Description.Text
data.value: Clears the server's cache and reloads the page.

data.name: Prompt_ClearCache_ResultHtml.Text
data.value:
clear-cache

Results

Cache cleared
Reloading in 3 seconds

data.name: Prompt_ClearHistory_Description.Text
data.value: Clears history of commands used in current session

data.name: Prompt_ClearLog_Description.Text
data.value: Clears the Event Log for the current portal.

data.name: Prompt_ClearLog_ResultHtml.Text
data.value:
clear-log

Results

[Event Log Cleared]

data.name: Prompt_Echo_Description.Text

data.name: Prompt_Exit_Description.Text

data.name: Prompt_GetHost_Description.Text
data.value: Retrieves information about the DNN installation

data.name: Prompt_GetHost_ResultHtml.Text

Get Information on Current DNN Installation

get-host

Version : 9.0.0.1002

Framework : 4.6
IP Address : fe80::a952:8263:d357:ab90%5

Container : Gravity (Title_h2)
EditTheme : Gravity (2-Col)
EditContainer : Gravity (Title_h2)
PortalCount : 1

data.name: Prompt_SetMode_Description.Text
data.value: Sets the DNN View Mode. This has the same effect as clicking the appropriate options in the DNN Control Bar.

data.name: Prompt_SetMode_FlagMode.Text

data.name: Prompt_CopyModule_ResultHtml.Text
data.value:
Copy a Module from One Page to Another

This command makes a copy of the module with Module ID 358 on the Page with Page ID of 71 and places that copy on the page with a Page ID of 75

copy-module 358 --pageid 71 --topageid 75

Results

ModuleId : 358
Title : My Module
ModuleName : DNN_HTML
FriendlyName : HTML
ModuleDefId : 120
TabModuleId : 107
AddedToPages : 71, 75
Successfully copied the module.
